nate – I
fear, my beloved

Chase away your idle

It will chill your frame with

then
far from being surprised

at my

I will

But

erne earnestly

I
know

In about a week after
this
the arrival of
Elizabeths letter

Elizabeth
wel
comed me with warm

yet

my
ematiated

I
also saw a change in
her—She
was
thinner
and had lost much of that heavenly viva

But her
softness
&
gentle
looks of
com
passion made her more fit for one
blasted & miserable as I was.
The
calm hower however
which
I now enjoyed did not
last. Recollection
brought madness with
it–
And when
I thought of what had
passed
a
realinsani
ty
possessed
me –
Sometimes I was
furious
& burnt with
rage
sometimes low
& des
pondant I neither spoke or looked
but sat motionless
bewildered by the
multitude of miseries that overcame
me. Elizabeth alone had the power
to draw me from these
fits –
Her gentle
voice would
sooth m
when
passionate
and inspire with
earthly human fee
lings when sunk in
torpor –
She
wept
with me
and for me.
When unhappy &
When reason

remonstrate

th for the guilty there is

I remained silent.
Have you
then,

some other
attachment
None
on
earth I replied
I love
Eliza
beth

with
delight—Let
the day therefore
be
named and I shall be
happy when it

my
life or
death

to of
my

My

do not speak thus. Heavy misfortunes

us us only

and

ameliorated
softened
your
despair &
new & dear
cares

fate has
we have been so cruelly

death was no evil to

if the loss of Eliza
beth were balanced with

therefore
with contented & even cheerful

father that the ceremony

and thus put, as I

the seal to

ry

self

outcast over

marriage – But

ed of magic

when

prepared only my own

the real
a far dearer

As the
time drew nearer
for our
marriage,

sink
with in me –
But I concealed
^
my feelings
this
by
under

smiles
to of
joy to the countenance of
my
father
but hardly deceived the
ever
watchful
& nicer eye of Elizabeth. She

content

fear
,

airy

&ever
lasting

Preparations were made for the

Congratulatory visits
^

appearance –I
shut
up m
as well

there
and entered with seeming ear
nestness into the plans of my
father
although

A house was purchased for us
near Coligny by which we should enjoy

day– who would still reside within the
walls for the benefit of Ernest, that he

ty.

at t ack we—

artifice

ed a greater
^

Elizabeth seemed

fil my wishes & my

^

following day. My father was in the mean time

&
but it was agreed that Elizabeth & I

Evian and set out on our return

as the wind

Those were the last moments of

the feeling

the

Be

I

Observe how fast we

clear

joy for a few instants shone in her
